likelihood: Enter your precise data to assess the likelihood of IBD.
BacteriesOptions: (0 – uncommon, 1 – trace, 2 – individual, 3 – quite frequent, 4 – numerous, 5 – abundant)
parasitesInTheStoolRequired: Parasites in the stool are required
calprotectinRequired: Calprotectin in the stool is required
reportModel: The result was obtained using a machine learning model based on a Random Forest Classifier. This is an ensemble learning model for classification and regression, which creates a set of decision trees to analyze data. Then, a majority voting process is carried out, and the result of this voting is the outcome of the algorithm.
reportDisclaimer: The prediction results generated by this machine learning model are for informational purposes only and do not constitute a medical diagnosis. The model does not replace the advice, diagnosis, or treatment provided by a qualified healthcare professional. Always consult a doctor or other appropriate healthcare provider for professional opinions and recommendations.
overview2: Learn more about inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), their classification, etiopathogenesis, diagnostics, and treatment pathways.
overview5: – a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the digestive system, primarily including Crohn's disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC). These conditions are characterized by recurrent episodes of inflammation leading to mucosal damage in the intestines.
overview7: – a chronic inflammatory disease limited to the outer mucosal layer of the colon and rectum, where inflammation is continuous within the affected tissues. Symptoms include bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and mucosal inflammation.
overview9: – a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, most commonly the terminal ileum and colon. Inflammation is transmural, involving all layers of the intestinal wall and leading to fistulas, abscesses, and intestinal strictures.
overview11: The most common types of IBD are ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn's disease (CD). Rare cases that cannot be clearly classified into the above categories due to features of both diseases are designated as unclassified inflammatory bowel diseases (UIBD). The Montreal classification is most commonly used in diagnostics, taking into account extent and severity for UC and age, location, and disease course for CD.
overview13: The etiology of IBD is not fully understood. Despite differences in pathogenic mechanisms, both diseases share common sources in areas such as genetic predisposition, environmental factors, gut microbiota composition, and immune system responses:
overview15: – associated with mutations in genes affecting the immune system, such as NOD2, ATG16L1, IRGM, IL23R, IL12B, JAK2, or STAT3.
overview17: – involve factors such as a diet high in fats and sugars but low in fiber, smoking, use of certain medications like nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), oral contraceptives, or antibiotics, stress, and a weakened immune system due to reduced exposure to gut bacteria over a lifetime.
overview23: Protective effects against IBD have been demonstrated by
overview26: – in the case of innate immunity, mutations in NOD2, ATG16L1, and IRGM disrupt processes such as microbial detection, autophagy, and epithelial barrier integrity, contributing to disease development. For adaptive immunity, which operates through targeted responses using specialized antibodies, studies have shown a link between lymphocyte subpopulations responsible for triggering immune responses, such as Th1, Th2, and Th17, and inflammatory bowel diseases.
overview28: IBD is diagnosed using colonoscopy, gastroduodenoscopy, and imaging studies such as ultrasound or magnetic resonance imaging. Additionally, laboratory markers (e.g., CRP, calprotectin) and serological markers (e.g., ANCA, ASCA) are analyzed.
overview30: IBD is currently incurable. Therapy focuses on symptom relief, as well as inducing and maintaining remission:
overview32: – e.g., mesalazine, particularly effective in UC.
overview34: – e.g., hydrocortisone, prednisolone, used to induce remission.
overview36: – e.g., thiopurines, methotrexate, limit inflammatory responses.
overview38: – e.g., infliximab, adalimumab, inhibit pro-inflammatory cytokines.
overview39: Despite their effectiveness, the above medications can be costly and cause various side effects.

tou1: User Guide for the Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) Prediction Model
tou2: To use our tool, follow the steps below:
tou4: In the first step, select the type of disease for which you want to obtain a prediction:
tou5: To do this, click the appropriate option from the dropdown list.
tou7: Next, enter the laboratory test results into the appropriate text fields. Each field is labeled with the name of the test and its unit to make data entry easier. Please enter the results carefully and precisely, ensuring they match the unit assigned to the field:
tou9: After entering all the data, click the 'Calculate' button. Your data will be sent to our machine learning model, which will analyze it based on a pre-trained algorithm.
tou11: After a few moments, the model will return a prediction result on the screen:
tou15: After receiving the result, you can generate a PDF report that includes analysis details, the prediction result, and full documentation of the entered data. To do this:
tou17: The report will be automatically generated and will be available for download or printing.
tou19: Only enter values that are up-to-date and verified by professionals.
tou20: Remember that our model is a tool for supporting diagnostics but does not replace medical advice. Always consult a doctor for interpretation of the results.
regulations1: Regulations for the IBD Diagnosis website
regulations2: These Regulations define the rules for using our website.
regulations4: Our website supports preliminary diagnostics of inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) using a machine learning model. The results are for informational purposes only and do not replace professional medical diagnostics.
regulations6: The website is intended for adults or individuals acting in consultation with a medical specialist.
regulations8: The user bears full responsibility for the accuracy of the data entered into the system.
regulations10: The website owner is not responsible for the interpretation of the results or decisions made based on them.
regulations12: Generated reports are stored locally by the user only.
regulations14: The website content is protected by copyrights. Its use for commercial purposes without the owner's consent is prohibited.
regulations16: The website owner reserves the right to change the regulations at any time.
regulations18: If you have any questions, please contact us via the
